awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  WeighCam: A Non-invasive Screening Tool to Detect Overweight Trucks on Roads in Real Time
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to decrease the number of overweight trucks on the roads by developing a financially and technically practical screening tool to detect overweight vehicles on most roads in real-time. Overweight commercial vehicles are a significant cause of the nation's crumbling roads and bridges besides being a prime threat to transportation safety.

The proposed project addresses the issue of effectively detecting overweight trucks on roads using real-time video-images while neither interfering with the traffic flow nor integrity the pavement. The proprietary system, WeighCam system, includes proprietary electro-optical system, algorithms, and system design. It will be easy to operate and robust in the sense that it will reliably work in most ambient environmental conditions such as ambient luminosity changes, etc. The purpose of this research will be to validate the basics of the system and calibrate the measurements using known weights to deduce the system limitations and to establish the feature sets of the Minimum Viable Product (MVP), a necessary step to start the manufacture of a commercial prototype. The final prototype will be a practical, autonomous, quick to install, and continuously operating continuous system sending data in real time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed project addresses the issue of effectively detecting overweight trucks on roads using real-time video-images while neither interfering with the traffic flow nor the integrity of the pavement.

Nearly 71% of U.S. freight moves by truck. Overloading is thought to be common due to a lack of effective deterrence on all roads. Overweight commercial vehicles are a significant contributor to the nation's crumbling roads and bridges. Any efforts to renovate or build new infrastructures will be hindered without addressing this issue broadly. Also, overloaded trucks are a significant safety risk. Overweight vehicles are difficult to maneuver. This causes the truck's mechanical components to be prone to failure. This in turn often causes crashes, with significant human and economic tolls, especially if the load is hazardous.

Phase I NSF R&D aimed to determine whether the novel WeighCamTM technology would be viable and how large its market would be. The product calculates a vehicle's weight based on the deflection it causes on a bridge as it traverses. Video images are used instead of equipment on the pavement to measure bridge deflection, so the technology is non-invasive, and no traffic disruption is caused. As a screening tool, the product alerts authorities without slowing traffic when overweight is detected. The technology's capability ultimately depends on its ability to measure various types of bridge deflection. 

During Phase I of the project, we were able to significantly improve the resolution of measurement in real-world conditions, enabling us to monitor a wide range of bridges, from stiff highway bypasses to flexible long suspension bridges with high signal-to-noise ratios.

This means that the system can be deployed almost everywhere in the country, which totals more than 617,000 bridges. 

A Minimum Viable Product (MVP) has also been defined as a result of Phase I. 

Phase I project targets were achieved and exceeded, leading to a Phase II SBIR NSF award for commercialization.

Modified by: Shervin Taghavi Larigani
